Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Fully Integrated Design and Automated Fabrication Services Software Platform for Engineering Living Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will be the development of a software platform for the engineering of living systems. Specifically, it will complete a software ecosystem that builds upon a core set of computational tools for the specification, design, build, test, analyze, and archive activities in synthetic biology and couple them with a rich set of interfaces to expert services (e.g., DNA synthesis, data analysis). The proposed work involves the completion of state-of-the-art design approaches and algorithms and couples it with the ability to create customized, modular workflows based on genetic circuit design, metabolic pathway modification, and genome engineering. The proposed work advances computational approaches in synthetic biology as well as innovating in the way that software services are monetized with biotechnology companies. The anticipated result of this work is a commercial software package and associated service agreements that can be deployed to both large and small biotechnology companies fundamentally changing the way that synthetic biology designs are conceived, designed, and physically created.

This SBIR Phase II project will develop a software platform where the goal is to combine bio-design automation (BDA) software with explicitly integrated access to expert services in a workflow-driven software ecosystem. The creation of novel living systems using biotechnology to engineer new medicines, materials, and fuels is frequently an ad-hoc process involving long iteration cycles, wasted resources, and sub-optimal designs. The software will allow for the automated specification, design, fabrication, test, and archival of complete plans for the engineering of novel engineered biological systems. This software includes mechanisms for specifying biological "rules," DNA assembly strategies, and automated generation of robotic instructions. In particular, this effort will focus on the creation of genetic circuits, engineered metabolic pathways, and genome engineering. The approach provides tools representing state-of-the-art advances in BDA while introducing novel methods of interacting with a large, diverse set of expert service providers. Further, the approach will empower novice experimentalists while enabling expert computational engineers.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Synthetic biology comprises a wide field of disciplines including agriculture, pharmaceuticals, bio-therapeutics, and energy production and consumption, among many others, all of which represent focal points of advancements in human health and prosperity, planetary resource protectionism, and stewardship of sentient life. The creation of novel living systems using biotechnology to engineer the new medicines, materials, and fuels that these industries develop is frequently an ad-hoc process involving long iteration cycles, wasted resources, and sub-optimal designs. The software technology Lattice produced as a part of the NSF SBIR Phase II award takes aim at these dated processes as news of ecosystem pillars collapsing, food shortages, and insufficient disease treatment and prevention is constant and ubiquitous. In order to meet the substantial and growing global needs, improvements and advances in biological engineering must be prioritized. The objective of the bio-design automation (BDA) technology Lattice produced is to enable design and build process improvements, advance state-of-the-art data collection and utilization techniques, and establish cross-industry channels to facilitate synergistic activity.

It is widely accepted that synthetic biology activities are inadequate to address global health issues or food shortages quickly. Moreover, it is known that the fastest time to market coupled with efficient use of resources are critical factors for business success and profit. The design and development cycles for new engineered biological systems are largely serial processes, error prone due to limited lab automation, and poorly architected for useful data capture and downstream learning. By developing state-of-the-art computational programs for specifying biological ?rules?, combinatorial DNA assembly strategies, generation and execution of automated lab protocols, and learning models for iteratively improving design efficacy from empirical data -- Lattice aims to supply the highly specialized innovators within the synthetic biology industry with tools for achieving the pace and scale of innovation required for modern solutions. Industry and academic leaders and doers acknowledge the need for current biological engineering practices to be augmented by modern computational advances. The field of innovation is limited by the technologies that support our scientists and experimentalists. We are optimistic that the technology Lattice has developed with the funding of the NSF SBIR Phase II award will contribute to the advancement of biological engineering toward expanded innovation scope and critical intellectual insights.

 


Last Modified: 03/12/2020
Modified by: Kevin G Leshane
